Prerequisites

In this text, we reinfornce knowledge about the numerical systems. For more details, we recommend starting with:

  • Drawing to count: show how we change from our fingers to geometric pictures.
  • Numerical families: Illustrating the relationship between our ancestors and numbers.

Rules

The goal of the game is to complete numerical sequences while respecting the maximum and minimum limits of the chosen numerical system. Before starting, select the level and numerical system you wish to use. In each step, two numbers will be presented, and you’ll need to determine the third using the available controls. For each correct answer, an indigenous tool will be revealed. Once you complete a level, click "Next" (), to continue. After finishing all 10 levels, you will earn a medal ().

The Hindu-Arabic and Mesoamerican numerical systems are presented within a single table. However, when playing with the Yupana system, comparisons are made between different tables, with smaller values appearing in the lower tables.

The Yupana method used in this game is based on the "Yupana Inka Tawa Pukllay", developed and published by Dhavit Prem (Prem, Dhavit) of Associação Yupanki (Prem, Dhavit, ).
The application of Mesoamerican numbers is grounded in the work of Orlando Josué Casares Contreras, José M. Gamboa Cetina and Venus Sarahí Estrella Cabrera (Casares Contreras, Orlando & Cetina, José & Cabrera, Venus Sarahí, , (ResearchGate) ; Casares Contreras, Orlando & Cetina, José & Cabrera, Venus Sarahí, , (Revista)). Additionally, we incorporate methods inspired by the work of Francisco Barriga Puente (Puente, Francisco Barriga, ).
Lastly, we employ various counting methods influenced by A. González Redondo et al. (González Redondo, Francisco A., et al., ).
